$!The way you manage pests and wildlife on your land depends on whether the species is protected under wildlife legislation or not. You may need to get a licence to kill, remove or disturb certain species. $!

The laws around wildlife protection are different in England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales. 

If particular species of birds or animals are legally protected, you may need to get a licence to cull them or to disturb their habitats. You'll usually need to have a good reason (eg they're attacking your crops or causing a public health problem).

Contact the relevant organisation in your area to find out which species are protected and what you can and can't do.

##England

Contact [Wildlife Management and Licensing](http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/regulation/wildlife/default.aspx "Wildlife Management and Licensing"){:rel="external"} at Natural England:

- for [advice](http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/regulation/wildlife/advice/advisoryleaflets.aspx "advisory leaflets"){:rel="external"} on dealing with birds and animals on your land
- to get a [licence](http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/regulation/wildlife/licences/default.aspx "Licences"){:rel="external"} if necessary   

$C **Wildlife Management and Licensing**    
  
<wildlife@naturalengland.org.uk>  
0845 6014523  $C

If you suspect an animal or bird has been poisoned, report it to the Wildlife Incident Investigation Scheme.

$C **Wildlife Incident Investigation Scheme**  

0800 321600 (freephone)  $C


##Northern Ireland

You'll need a licence to:

- remove bats from your building or disturb their habitat for development work
- kill or move certain birds, or take their eggs 
- keep or breed some birds of prey

[Download licence forms or apply for licences online](http://www.doeni.gov.uk/niea/biodiversity/wildlife_management_and_licensing/wildlife.htm "Wildlife Licensing"){:rel="external"} to the Biodiversity Unit, Northern Ireland Environment Agency. You can also get advice on related topics, such as using rat poison on your land or photographing wildlife.

$C **Biodiversity Unit**

028 9056 9605
$C


##Scotland

Find out [your legal responsibilities](http://www.snh.gov.uk/protecting-scotlands-nature/protected-species/your-responsibilities/ "Your responsibilities"){:rel="external"} if you encounter wildlife as part of your job (eg as a developer, land manager or researcher) or as a member of the public. 

Scottish Natural Heritage also has information on [activities that need a licence](http://www.snh.gov.uk/protecting-scotlands-nature/species-licensing/ "Species licensing"){:rel="external"} and how you can apply for one.

$C **Scottish Natural Heritage**  
  
[www.snh.org.uk](http://www.snh.org.uk "Scottish Natural Heritage"){:rel="external"}  
<enquiries@snh.gov.uk>  
01463 725 000
$C


##Wales

If moles are causing damage or harm to agricultural land (eg damaging plant growth or grass-cutting machinery), you can only control them by trapping them or gassing them using aluminium phosphide. 

For advice on managing other wildlife, eg badgers, on your land, contact the Welsh Assembly Government.

$C **Welsh Assembly Government**  
  
0300 062 2297  
0300 062 2290  
0300 062 2241  
   $C

If you suspect an animal or bird has been poisoned, report it to the Wildlife Incident Investigation Scheme.

$C **Wildlife Incident Investigation Scheme**  

0800 321600 (freephone)  $C
